citations.narrative:
In mid-September 2023, a yearling male moose “Duck Moses” escaped from his enclosure. The moose got out of its
primary enclosure and then walked through an open gate in the perimeter fencing. Despite several days of searching the
moose was not recovered prior to the start of hunting season. On December 23rd, 2023, the moose returned to the area
and was lured back inside the facility. The moose mingled with the wild moose population for over three months
potentially transmitting or contracting diseases or parasites, was exposed to predation and hunting threats without natural
fear of humans, and was without natural survival skills as he was bottle raised in captivity. These could have led to injury,
disease or death of the moose.
The facility must be constructed appropriately for the animals and maintained in good repair to protect and contain the
animals.
To be corrected by: 8/1/2024

In the shipping container used for feed storage, a large amount of rodent droppings were present on the floor mixed in
with hay and shavings. A large pile of shrimp was disintegrating on the ground outside the container which could attract
vermin and pests to the storage area. Pests and vermin could get into the feed and cause contamination, molding or
deterioration which could cause lack of palatability, disease or death to the animals.
Supplies of food and bedding must be stored in facilities which adequately protect against deterioration, molding, or
contamination by vermin.
To be corrected by 7/1/24.

The >8 ft chain link fence which serves as the perimeter fence for the one female brown bear enclosure is sagging
between poles reducing the height to below 8 feet providing less than adequate protection and containment for the
animal. Perimeter fencing for dangerous animals must be greater than 8 ft high to protect the animal from people or other
animals having contact with the animal and function as a secondary containment system for the animal.
To be corrected by 7/1/24

Several enclosures had excessive buildup up old bedding materials, debris, fecal material and food waste. The most west
lynx enclosure had large amounts of old bones and fecal material built up and licensee stated the enclosure has not been
cleaned yet this year. The fox enclosures along the south-western corner had a build up of old bones and wet bedding.
The wolverine enclosure had a large accumulation of bones with rotting flesh. Accumulation of food waste, bedding and
fecal material can attract pests and vermin and lead to disease and illness in the animals.
Cleaning of enclosures must be done as often as necessary to prevent contamination of the animals and to minimize
disease hazards and to reduce odors.
To be corrected by 7/1/24
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with licensee.
